Introduction

Bradycardia is defined as a slow ventricular rate <60/min.  It can occur as a normal physiologic response (eg, enhanced vagal tone due to endurance training) or a result of pathology (eg, age-related conduction system degeneration).  Pathologic causes of bradycardia can lead to signs and symptoms of low cardiac output or, in severe cases, sudden cardiac arrest.

Pathophysiology

Sinoatrial node



The sinoatrial node is the normal pacemaker of the heart, rhythmically generating impulses that travel through the conduction system and drive the coordinated contraction of the atria and ventricles.  Normally, the sinoatrial node spontaneously generates impulses at a rate of 60-100/min, with the rate of impulse generation determined by the balance of parasympathetic and sympathetic input.  Slow generation of sinoatrial node impulses usually occurs due to enhanced parasympathetic tone, pharmacologic effects, or sinus node dysfunction.

Other intrinsic pacemaker cells



If the sinoatrial node begins to fail, more distal parts of the conduction system also have an intrinsic pacemaker that can spontaneously generate impulses, but at a slower rate (

figure 1
).  When these more distal pacemaker cells (eg, in the atrioventricular [AV] junction) do not receive a timely impulse from the sinoatrial node, they become the primary pacemaker of the heart, maintaining a slower rate of ventricular contraction



The AV node relays electrical impulses from the atria to the ventricles, and AV node dysfunction can contribute to bradycardia.  Like the sinoatrial node, the AV node conduction rate is subject to pharmacologic effects and increases in parasympathetic tone.  Ischemia and age-related cellular degeneration can also cause AV node dysfunction.

Causes of bradycardia

Physiologic



  • Endurance training:  Physiologic adaptations to high-intensity endurance training allow for increased stroke volume.  Resting vagal tone is increased because this increased stroke volume makes it possible for a lower heart rate to maintain adequate resting cardiac output.
  • Sleep:  Increased vagal tone during sleep can lead to physiologic bradycardia.

Pathophysiologic



  • Sinus node dysfunction (ie, sick sinus syndrome) from age-related fibrosis of the sinoatrial node can lead to impaired impulse generation.  Less commonly, age-related fibrosis and calcification of the AV node, His bundle, and bundle branches can lead to AV block and cause or contribute to bradycardia.
  • Acute myocardial infarction of the inferior wall, usually due to occlusion of the right coronary artery, is commonly complicated by bradycardia.  The bradycardia likely results primarily from ischemia affecting the sinoatrial and AV nodes (
    figure 2
    ), possibly with some contribution of enhanced parasympathetic tone and adenosine secretion triggered by infarction of myocardial tissue.
  • Sleep disordered breathing (eg, obstructive sleep apnea) can lead to prolonged apneas associated with hypoxemia.  These cause increased parasympathetic tone that can induce sinus bradycardia, sinus pauses, and AV block.
  • Elevated intracranial pressure (eg, intracranial hemorrhage, brain tumor) leads to reflex bradycardia due to an increase in parasympathetic tone (Cushing reflex).
  • Infections such as Lyme carditis (Borrelia burgdorferi) can disrupt AV node conduction and cause bradycardia.  Infective endocarditis can be complicated by a perivalvular abscess causing AV block.
  • Infiltrative disease (eg, sarcoidosis, amyloidosis) can disrupt AV node conduction and cause bradycardia.
  • Hypothyroidism can cause bradycardia likely due to a direct effect of inadequate thyroid hormone on the sinoatrial node and reduced metabolic demand in the tissues.
  • Anorexia nervosa is associated with bradycardia primarily resulting from reduced metabolic demand and elevated parasympathetic tone.
  • Hypothermia decreases the rate of sinoatrial node impulse conduction independent of parasympathetic tone.
  • Prolonged hypoxemia can cause sinoatrial node ischemia and resulting bradycardia.

Other



  • Pharmacologic agents usually cause bradycardia via a relative increase in parasympathetic stimulus to both the sinoatrial node and AV node.  Common responsible agents include:
    • Acetylcholine, acetylcholinesterase inhibitors
    • Beta blockers, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers
    • Digoxin
  • Sedatives (eg, opioids, benzodiazepines) can cause bradycardia via CNS depression.

Clinical presentation



Mild bradycardia is typically asymptomatic.  Patients with a ventricular rate <50/min may present with symptoms of reduced cardiac output:



  • Dyspnea
  • Angina
  • Lightheadedness
  • Syncope

Physical examination



Palpation of the radial pulse reveals a slow rate.  The rhythm is usually regular but may be irregular in patients with sinus pauses or second-degree AV block.

ECG:  Impaired sinoatrial conduction



The P wave on ECG is created by depolarization of the atria, which normally originates in the sinoatrial node.  Therefore, impaired sinoatrial conduction is evidenced on ECG by reduced frequency of sinus P waves.

Sinus bradycardia and sinus pause/arrest



Sinus bradycardia demonstrates a slow and regular rhythm with normally shaped P waves preceding each QRS complex (

image 1
).  When sinus node dysfunction is present, other findings that can be seen with sinus bradycardia include the following:



  • A sinus pause occurs when the sinoatrial node impulse generation is later than expected (based on the underlying sinus rhythm), and a P wave is delayed (
    image 2
    ).
  • Sinus arrest is a prolonged sinus pause that is so delayed that an intrinsic pacemaker below the sinoatrial node (usually in the AV junction) generates its own beat.  The P wave is dropped (does not occur) and a junctional QRS complex occurs.

Junctional escape rhythm



With complete sinus node failure (continuous sinus arrest), an intrinsic pacemaker further down the conduction system becomes the primary pacemaker for the heart.  ECG demonstrates no sinus P waves and typically a junctional escape rhythm, with the intrinsic pacemaker of the AV node generating impulses after failing to receive an impulse from the sinoatrial node (

image 3
).

ECG:  Atrioventricular node blocks



The PR interval on ECG is mostly representative of conduction through the AV node.  Therefore, AV nodal block is recognized by alterations in the PR interval:

First-degree AV block



  • First-degree AV block (
    image 4
    ) results from slowed conduction through the AV node and manifests on ECG as a prolonged PR interval >0.2 sec.  Because AV conduction is generally intact (other than being slowed slightly), first-degree AV block does not cause bradycardia by itself.

Second-degree AV block (Mobitz type 1 and 2)



  • Mobitz type 1 (Wenckebach) second-degree AV block (
    image 5
    ) usually results from disrupted conduction within the AV node.  It manifests on ECG as progressive lengthening of the PR interval followed by a dropped QRS complex.
  • Mobitz type 2 second-degree AV block (
    image 6
    ) usually results from disrupted conduction below the AV node (eg, in the His bundle).  It manifests on ECG with a PR interval that is constant in duration, but with randomly dropped QRS complexes.

Third-degree (complete) AV block



  • Third-degree (complete) AV block (
    image 7
    ) involves complete blockage of AV conduction.  Sinus P waves occur at regular intervals, but the impulses are not transmitted to the ventricles.  QRS complexes are driven by a separate pacemaker below the AV node and occur at regular intervals.  The P waves and QRS complexes have no relation to one another (AV dissociation).

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of bradycardia may be suspected based on clinical presentation and can often be confirmed with a pulse check.  ECG or cardiac monitoring can also confirm the ventricular rate (

figure 3
); it is needed to determine the particular conduction disturbance causing bradycardia (eg, sinus bradycardia, AV block).



Chronotropic incompetence (ie, failure of the sinoatrial node to adequately increase conduction rate during exercise) is often seen during exercise testing in patients with sinus node dysfunction and can be helpful in confirming the diagnosis.

Management

Asymptomatic bradycardia



Most patients with bradycardia who are asymptomatic require no intervention.

Symptomatic bradycardia



Patients with bradycardia and symptoms of low cardiac output (eg, lightheadedness, dyspnea) should undergo investigation of the underlying cause followed by appropriate treatment (eg, dose reduction of beta blocker therapy, treatment of Lyme carditis causing AV block) (

figure 4
).

Hemodynamic instability



  • Patients with bradycardia causing hemodynamic instability (eg, hypotension, chest pain, syncope) should receive 1 mg intravenous atropine, which can be repeated every 3-5 minutes for a total dose of 3 mg.  Of note, atropine may worsen bradycardia in patients with Mobitz type II second-degree AV block (

    ).
  •   If hemodynamic instability persists despite the administration of intravenous atropine, the patient should be initiated on transcutaneous or transvenous pacing.  Alternatively, an intravenous infusion of dopamine or epinephrine can be attempted prior to pacing.

Permanent pacemaker placement



Patients with symptomatic bradycardia that does not have a reversible cause typically require placement of a permanent pacemaker (

figure 5
).  Conditions that represent strong indications for permanent pacemaker placement include:



  • Sinus node dysfunction
  • Mobitz type II second-degree AV block
  • Third-degree (complete) AV block


First-degree AV block does not cause symptoms and Mobitz type I second-degree AV block rarely causes symptoms; no intervention is typically indicated for these conditions (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).

Complications



  • Severe bradycardia can occasionally cause sudden cardiac arrest (due to markedly reduced cardiac output).  Sudden cardiac arrest in the setting of bradycardia is managed as pulseless electrical activity in the cardiopulmonary resuscitation algorithm (
    figure 6
    ).
  • Tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome is a common complication seen in patients with sinus node dysfunction.  It involves sinus bradycardia that alternates with supraventricular arrhythmias, most commonly atrial fibrillation.  Fibrosed and dysfunctional atrial conduction tissue likely creates susceptibility for ectopic foci of atrial conduction to supersede the conduction of the impaired sinoatrial node.  Severe bradycardia can occur on spontaneous conversion from atrial fibrillation to sinus rhythm, placing patients at risk for syncope.
  • A permanent pacemaker increases the risk of infective endocarditis; infective endocarditis involving a permanent pacemaker typically requires full removal of the device, which is associated with increased morbidity and mortality.

Prognosis



The prognosis in patients with bradycardia is driven primarily by the underlying cause of bradycardia.  Physiologic causes (eg, endurance training) do not require treatment and have an excellent prognosis.  Bradycardia due to sinus node dysfunction or advanced AV block is effectively treated with placement of a permanent pacemaker, and patients generally have a favorable prognosis.

Summary



Bradycardia is defined as a slow ventricular rate <60/min.  It can result from slowed impulse generation in the sinoatrial node or impaired relay of conduction through the atrioventricular node and can be a normal physiologic response or a result of pathology.  Pathologic causes of bradycardia can lead to signs and symptoms of low cardiac output or, in severe cases, sudden cardiac arrest.  Symptomatic bradycardia with an irreversible cause typically requires placement of a permanent pacemaker.
